text: So once more, how would you say I can understand it?
Je peux le comprendre.
And I can understand him?
Je peux le comprendre.
I can understand her.
Je peux la comprendre.
What is to give, literally to donate in French?
Donner.
How would you say I can give?
Je peux donner.
How would you say he can give?
Il peut donner.
How would you say to give it in French?
Le donner.
How about to give me?
Me donner.
How do you think you would say to give it to me?
Me le donner.
Now when you get more than one word like this and you want to put it in front, it's obviously hard to work out how to order it.
Which one goes first?
Which one goes where?
So I should give you a very simple rule.
And that is that L is for last.
So if you have something beginning with an L, it goes last.
Here we have me and it.
And the it begins with an L and the me obviously begins with an M.
And so to give it to me, the one beginning with the L goes last.
Let's try that again.
How would you say to give it to me?
Me le donner.
What is you formal can in French?
How would you say you can give it to me?
Vous pouvez me le donner.
How would you say can you give it to me by inverting the word order?
Pouvez-vous me le donner?
Can you give it to me this evening?
Pouvez-vous me le donner ce soir?
To him in French, to him is lui.
How would you say can you give to him?
Pouvez-vous lui donner?
Now, before we say can you give it to him, we have a dilemma.
So far I've told you that L is for last.
But we're going to end up with two L's here.
Again, what was to him in French?
Lui.
The first rule we learnt about the order was L is for last.
So the L's go last.
If you have something with an L and something beginning with another letter, the L goes last.
If you have two beginning with L, however, the rule is that Louis goes last.
So L is last, but if you've got two L's, then Louis goes last.
So how would you say to give it to him?
You can give it to him.
You can give it to him.
Can you give it to him?
Can you give it to him this evening?
Can you give it to me this evening?
Can you give it to me this evening?
So here you have both rules being applied.
The first rule is L is always last.
So L always goes last.
But if you have to beginning with L, Louis goes last.
So again, what was to him in French?
Lui.
To her in French is Lui.
So it's the same.
So how would you say, can you give it to her?
Pouvez-vous le lui donner?
And you can give it to her?
Vous pouvez le lui donner.
How would you say, you can't give it to her?
Vous ne pouvez pas le lui donner.
So once more, L is for last.
But if you have two L's, Louis goes last.
This is the end of CD9.
You can give it to her.
And you can give it to her.
And you can give it to her.
And you can give it to her.
You can give it to her.
